awd_titl_txt: Conference: Riverside Geometric Group Theory Workshop 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
Geometric group theory is active area at the interface of geometry, algebra, and dynamical systems, which has seen many break-through results over the past decades, with many applications especially to low-dimensional topology. This award provides funding for the first Riverside Workshop on Geometric Group Theory, which is to be held March 27-31 2023 at the University of California Riverside.  This workshop will feature four minicourses given by early-career mathematicians working in the field.  The topic of each minicourse will be a cutting-edge technique or idea developed by the speaker, with an audience of graduate students and postdocs in mind.  Each speaker will also produce an expository paper on the topic of their minicourse, and these papers will be compiled into a book.

Much of the machinery in geometric group theory is highly technical, and so graduate students looking to enter the field will benefit from careful exposition of the big ideas of the field in lecture series that elaborate extensively on background and examples.  The invited minicourse speakers are: Matthew Durham (University of California, Riverside), who will speak on the hierarchical geometry of mapping class groups and surface bundles; Anne Lonjou (Université Paris-Saclay), who will speak on applications of geometric group theory to algebraic geometry; Marissa Kawehi Loving (University of Wisconsin-Madison), who will speak on the geometry of mapping class groups of infinite-type surfaces and their mapping tori; and Jean-Pierre Mutanguha (Institute for Advanced Study), who will speak on the geometry of mapping tori of free group automorphisms.  For more information, please see the conference website: https://sites.google.com/view/riggthew-2023/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award "Conference: Riverside Geometric Group Theory Workshop 2023" funded two successful meetings aimed at PhD students, both of which were held in Riverside, CA. The first of these was held in March 2023, and featured four mini-courses by prominent junior researchers in geometric group theory. The topics of these mini-courses were cutting edge research directions to which each of the speakers has made substantial contributions. The audience consisted almost entirely of PhD students, with a large percentage of the participants belonging to underrepresented demographics. The talks were livestreamed in order to further increase the reach of the conference. Each of the mini-courses was introduced by a PhD student speaker, which gave these students the opportunity to practice discussing high level mathematics in a supportive environment.

The mini-course speakers also committed to writing a useable expository article based on their lectures. These have all been collected and are currently undergoing peer review. The American Mathematical Society has agreed to publish these articles in a volume of the "Contemporary Mathematics" series.

The second meeting funded by this award was held in January 2024. The second meeting featured one mini-course, and an audience almost exclusively of PhD students, the majority of which were from California or the west coast. The lectures from this meeting were also livestreamed, and the mini-course was preceded by an introductory student lecture.

The workshop speakers and attendees were largely from underrepresented gender and racial groups, including all speakers and 19 of 24 and 13 of 15 participants (82% average) in the March 2023 and January 2024 editions, respectively.  Surveys indicate that the workshops have been impactful.

The following are some comments from surveys after the workshops:

"This workshop was one of the most thoughtfully-created group learning environments I've been in." ---RivGGT23 participant Aisha Mechery (Rice)

"The math was great! It was a good environment to ask questions at any level." ---RivGGT23 participant Paige Hillen (UC Santa Barbara)

"I *really* enjoyed the talks! I think the speaker choice and difference in topics was excellent. I thought the speakers did a good job of introducing the topics and slowly diving into their specific sub fields." ---RivGGT23 participant Brandis Whitfield

"I thought the mathematical aspects of the workshop were amazing!  It made me really excited about where my own research might be going and I was very happy to meet fellow researchers in the specific Coxeter/Artin group community, but also in the overall GGT community." ---RivGGT Jan 24 participant Alfredo Ramirez (UC Santa Barbara)
